question.name: GenesByOldAnnotation
question.summary: Find genes that have modified annotation with respect those in previous release.
question.description: Find genes that have modified annotation with respect those in previous release. Modified annotation includes GO and EC assignments, product names and coding sequence.

question.name: GenesByLocation
question.summary: Find genes that are located in a specified genomic region.
question.description:
Find genes within a given genomic region.
Select a genomic sequence from the pull-down menu and/or enter a genomic sequence ID from any of the available Fungi or Oomycetes species (eg. ScerS288C_Chr03, CgatR265_SC05, TmesDSM1558_SC01, HyaarEmoy2_SC01). If you supply both, your result will include the union. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes within a given genomic region.
Select a B. bovis, T. annulata, or T. parva chromosome from the pull-down menu or enter a genomic sequence ID. (If you supply both, your result will include the union). The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes within a given genomic region.
Enter a genomic sequence ID for any E. histolytica, E. dispar or E. invadens contig. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes within a given genomic region.
Select a E. intestinalis or E. cuniculi chromosome from the pull-down menu or enter a genomic sequence ID. (If you supply both, your result will include the union). The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes within a given genomic region.
Select a Leishmania or Trypanosoma chromosome from the pull-down menu or enter a genomic sequence ID. (If you supply both, your result will include the union). The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes within a given genomic region.
Select a C. parvum chromosome from the pull-down menu or enter the name of a contig for either C. parvum (e.g."CM000431"), C. hominis (e.g."AAEL01000057") or C. muris scaffolds (e.g."scf_43"). If you enter both, your result will include the union. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes that are located in a specified genomic region.

Select a genomic sequence from the pull-down menu and/or enter a genomic sequence ID from any Plasmodium species (if you supply both, your result will include the union). The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes within a given genomic region.
Either select an organism and a genomic sequence from the pull-down menu or enter a genomic sequence ID from any EuPathDB species (e.g. "AAEL01000057", "Pf3D7_04", "TGME49_chrIa", "ctg02_305", "DS170425"). The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes within a given genomic region.
Enter a genomic sequence ID for any T. vaginalis contig. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

Find genes within a given genomic region.
Enter a genomic sequence ID for any G. lamblia contig. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the sequence.

Find genes that are located in a specified genomic region.

Here you can retrieve genes based on their chromosomal location in either T. gondii or N. caninum. For example, all genes located on chromosome Ia can be retrieved by selecting "Ia" from the chromosome pull-down menu, and entering "1" in the "start at" field and "0" in the "End Location" field.
Alternatively, genes can be obtained by entering a specific sequence ID:
Chromosome ID examples: T. gondii ME49 chromosome VIIa = TGME49_chrVIIa; T. gondii VEG chromosome VIIa = TGVEG_chrVIIa; T. gondii GT1 chromosome VIIa = TGGT1_chrVIIa; N. caninum chromosome VIIa = NEO_chrVIIa.
T. gondii scaffold ID example: DS984804 (ME49), scf_1104442824720 (VEG or GT1) -- remember, not all scaffolds contain genes.
Contig ID example (only N. caninum): Contig1086.
If you enter a specific ID and select a chromosome from the pull-down menu, your result will include the union. The Start and End locations correspond to the coordinates of the gene(s) on the chromosome.

question.name: GenesByGeneDeprecationStatus
question.summary: Find genes that have been deprecated, or were deprecated in the past, but are deprecated presently.
question.description:
Find the genes from Giardia lamblia assemblage A isolate WB that were once deprecated, and later undeprecated based on proteomics evidence and/or synteny to assemblage B and E genomes.

Note: that deprecated genes were labeled as such because they appear unlikely to represent true genes, based on incompatibility with longer gene models or alternative models for which functional evidence is available. A number of deprecated genes may in fact be true genes and as evidence becomes available to support this, we will elevate a deprecated gene to a "full" gene status.We encourage users to notify us of such evidence by email or by adding specific user comments gene pages.

question.description: Find T. brucei genes by phenotype based on RNAi knockdown and insufficiency studies.

question.description: Find genes whose protein product has an isoelectric point in the specified range.

question.name: GenesByMolecularWeight
question.summary: Find genes whose unmodified protein product has a molecular weight in a range that you specify.
question.description:
Find genes whose unmodified protein product has a molecular weight in a range that you specify.

Molecular weights are machine calculated from the raw translation and does not take into account any protein or residue modifications. For translations containing ambiguous amino acid codes (B, Z, X) we calculate the average of the upper and lower bound of the molecular weight.

question.name: GenesBySecondaryStructure
question.summary: Find genes whose proteins are predicted to have the given secondary-structure content by the PSIPRED program.
question.description:
Find genes whose proteins are predicted to have the given secondary-structure content by the PSIPRED program. The percent composition is computed by counting the amino acids in which one of the three calls is given the highest confidence, and dividing by the length of the protein. For example the percent helix is the number of amino acids in which helix has the highest confidence, divided by the length of the protein. 

References: 
 Jones DT. (1999) Protein secondary structure prediction
 based on position-specific scoring matrices
 J Mol Biol. 1999 Sep 17;292(2):195-202

question.name: GenesByEcNumber
question.summary: Find genes by assigned Enzyme Commission (EC) number.
question.description:
Find P. falciparum, P. yoelii and/or P. knowlesi genes by their Enzyme Commission (EC) number. Use '-' in place of numbers to denote partial EC Numbers, for example, '2.7.7.-'. You may use '*' as a wild card character. For help with obtaining EC numbers, try the ExPASy-ENZYME browser.

E.C. number annotation for P. falciparum are from Andy Berry, Matt Berriman (Sanger Institute) and Hagai Ginsburg (Hebrew University).

Find genes by their Enzyme Commission (EC) number. Use '-' in place of numbers to denote partial EC Numbers, for example, '2.7.7.-'. You may use '*' as a wild card character. For help with obtaining EC numbers, try the ExPASy-ENZYME browser.

Find Cryptosporidium genes that have been assigned a particular Enzyme Commission (EC) number. Use '-' in place of numbers to denote partial EC Numbers, for example, '2.7.7.-'. You may use '*' as a wild card character.

E.C. numbers have been assigned to Cryptosporidium genes by the genome annotation centers, KEGG and CryptoCyc.

Find genes by their Enzyme Commission (EC) number. Use '-' in place of numbers to denote partial EC Numbers, for example, '2.7.7.-'. You may use '*' as a wild card character.

E.C. number annotation for Toxoplasma gondii are from Ian Paulsen (TIGR)

Find genes that have been assigned a particular Enzyme Commission (EC) number. Use '-' in place of numbers to denote partial EC Numbers, for example, '2.7.7.-'. You may use '*' as a wild card character.

For help with obtaining EC numbers, try the ExPASy-ENZYME browser.

CryptoDB EC numbers have been assigned by the genome annotation centers, KEGG and CryptoCyc. PlasmoDB EC numbers have been assigned to genes for P. falciparum by Andy Berry, Matt Berriman (Sanger Institute) and Hagai Ginsburg (Hebrew University). ToxoDB EC numbers have been assigned by Ian Paulsen (TIGR). E.C. number annotation for Toxoplasma gondii are from Ian Paulsen (TIGR)

question.name: GenesBySnps

propertyList.name: organism
propertyList.value: P. falciparum, T gondii, C. parvum

question.summary: Find genes which have SNPs meeting specific criteria (Non-synonymous / synonymous SNP ratio, SNP density, etc).
question.description:
Search for genes by SNP density, the number of SNPs of different classes, ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous, etc. Note that if you do not care about one of the parameters, don't change the defaults on that parameter and you will get all genes irrespective of that parameter. For example, running this search to compare 3D7 and Dd2 using default parameters returns 2577 genes. Among the top 20 on the list are CLAG, AMA1, chloroquine resistance marker and multiple PfEMP1 and SURFIN genes.

Note: Due to the extreme codon bias in the falciparum genome, the ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous snps per gene is much higher than expected so this should be considered when creating queries. We are intending to calculate more reliable normalized Dn/Ds or Ka/Ks ratios in subsequent releases of PlasmoDB.

Search for genes by SNP density, the number of SNPs of different classes, ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous, etc. Note that if you don't care about one of the parameters, don't change the defaults on that parameter and you will get all genes that contain SNPs between the reference and comparator strains irrespective of that parameter. See the Data Sources link below for experimental details.

For example, running this search to compare 3D7 and Dd2 using default parameters returns 2577 genes. Among the top 20 on the list are CLAG, AMA1, chloroquine resistance marker and multiple PfEMP1 and SURFIN genes.

question.name: GenesByMassSpec
question.summary: Find E. histolytica genes that have evidence for protein expression in phagosomes.
Find C. parvum genes that have evidence for protein expression in male and female gametocytes.
Find P. berghei , P. falciparum and P. yoelii genes that have evidence for protein expression.
Find T. gondii genes that have evidence for protein expression in male and female gametocytes.
Find T. vaginalis genes that have evidence for protein expression.
Find E. histolytica, C. parvum,G. lamblia, P. berghei , P. falciparum, P. yoelii, T. vaginalis, and T. gondii genes that have evidence for protein expression.
Find G. lamblia genes that have evidence for protein expression in male and female gametocytes.
question.description:
Find genes that have evidence for protein expression

  • Concanavalin A-enriched Glycoproteins from Trophozoite (Carpentieri et. al.)
    Total protein extract (soluble fraction) from E. histolytica trophozoites was purified over a Concanavalin A column followed by tryptic digestions and N-glycanase F hydrolysis (to release N-linked glycans and identify glycosylation sites). Proteins were analyzed by liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS).
    For more information please refer to: Carpentieri et. al., Eukaryotic Cell, 2010

  • Purified Uropods from Trophozoite (Markiewicz et. al.)
    Uropod extruded fractions were purified following a Concanavalin A incubation of E. histolytica trophozoites. Purification was performed by successive centrifugation and final pellet was processed for proteomics analysis. Proteins were analyzed by liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS).
    For more information please refer to: Markiewicz et. al., PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases, 2011

  • Magnetic Bead-Purified Phagosomes from Trophozoite (Boettner et. al.)
    Ingested carboxylated magnetic beads within intact phagosomes from E. histolytica were separated from amoebic lysate and subjected to delipidation and mass spectrometry sequencing. Phagosome preparations were performed at 0, 5, 10, and 60 minutes following centrifugation of the beads into contact with trophozoites. In addition lysed amoeba were incubated with beads and subjected to the same steps to account for background binding to the carboxylated beads. This resultant proteome identified many proteins previously associated with phagocytosis in the literature, including: the galactose binding lectin, small GTPases, hydrolytic proteins, cytoskeleton proteins, and endoplasmic reticulum proteins.
    For more information please refer to: Boettner et. al., PLoS Pathogens, 2008

  • Human Serum Coated Magnetic Bead-Purified Phagosomes from Trophozoite (Marion et. al.)
    Phagosomes were purified from E. histolytica wild type and myosin IB over-expressing (MyoIB+) trophozoites using human serum-coated magnetic beads. Phagosomes from wild type parasites were purified following a 3 minute incubation with beads, and phagosomes from MyoIB+ parasites were purified following 5 or 15 minute incubations. Proteins were analyzed by liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS).
    For more information please refer to: Marion et. al., Cellular Microbiology, 2005
Find genes that have evidence for protein expression

Find genes that have evidence for protein expression

  • G. intestinalis mitosome enriched fraction - nanoLC/MALDI TOF/TOF.
    For more information please refer to: Rada et. al., Eukaryotic Cell, 2009

  • Isolate WB DTA-Select Filter
    WB (genome project strain) Giardia lamblia grown axenically in TYI-S-33 medium supplemented with bile salts. Adherent trophozoites were harvested during log-phase growth (60-70% confluent) and proteins extracted in 8M Urea and SDS. 1 mg of extracted protein was digested with sequencing-grade modified trypsin and fractionated via strong cation exchange chromatography into 90 fractions. Each fraction was run via C-18 reverse phase chromatography and analyzed using an LTQ ProteomeX ion trap mass spectrometer (Thermo Finnigan). Peptide assignments were made using SEQUEST, and the individual runs were compiled using DTASelect.Protocol adapted from Jaffe, J.D., Berg, H.C, Church, G. M. Proteogenomic mapping as a complementary method to perform genome annotation. Proteomics, 2004, 4, 59-7
    Data provided by Daniel M. Ratner, Michael Lubrano, Martin Steffen, John Samuelson. University of Washington, Department of Bioengineering.

Find genes based on protein expression data from mass spectrometry experiments.


PlasmoDB includes a search against P. berghei genes that have protein expression evidence across different life cycle stages. This data was provided without peptide sequences hence peptide mapping to genes is not available. This search has been moved here: P.b. life cycle Mass Spec. Evidence
Find genes that have evidence for protein expression

Find genes that have evidence for protein expression

T. cruzi


  • Life cycle stages (Attwood et al.)
    Metacyclic trypomastigotes, amastigotes, trypomastigotes, and epimastigotes of T. cruzi Brazil strain were isolated and proteins were extracted from whole-cell or subcellular lysates. Digested peptides from protein preparations were analyzed by offline LC, and online LC-MS/MS.
    For more information please refer to: Attwood et. al, Science 2005

  • Reservosome proteome (Sant'Anna et al.)
    Reservosomes were isolated from T. cruzi epimastigotes (clone Dm28c) and a membrane fraction was prepared from a portion of the purified organelles. Total protein from intact reservosomes or membrane fractions were analyzed by LC-MS/MS.
    For more information please refer to: Sant'Anna et al., Proteomics. 2009

  • Insect form membrane proteins (Cordero et al.)
    Epimastigotes and metacyclic trypomastigotes of the T cruzi strain G were isolated and used to prepare GPI-anchored membrane protein-enriched samples. Protein samples were analyzed by 2DLC-MS/MS.
    For more information please refer to: Cordero et al., Journal Proteome Research 2009



T. brucei


  • Mitochondrion of procyclic form (Panigrahi et al.)
    Mitochondrial vesicles from T. brucei IsTaR 1.7a were lysed and separated into detergent soluble and insoluble fractions. Proteins in detergent soluble fractions were analyzed by 2DLC-MS/MS. Proteins in insoluble fractions were analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS.
    For more information please refer to: Panigrahi et al., Proteomics 2009

  • Bloodstream form phosphoproteome (Nett et al.)
    Proteins were precipitated from the cytosolic fraction of bloodstream form T. brucei (RUMP 528) cells. Proteins were digested and Phosphorylated and nonphosphorylated peptides were separated by SCX chromotography. Phosphopeptides were enriched by TiO2 chromotography, and analyzed by LC-MS/MS.
    For more information please refer to: Nett et al., Mol Cell Proteomics 2009

  • Procyclic form palmitoylated proteins (Emmer et al.)
    Proteins from whole cell lysates of T. brucei procyclic form 29-13 strain were biotinylated at the site of palmitoylation and purified by streptavidin chromatography. Streptavidin eluates were precipitated and proteins preparations were analyzed by LC-MS/MS.
    The search associated with this data returns both palmitoylated and non-palmitoylated proteins. Only a subset of the proteins returned by this search are palmitoylated. To view this list click here.
    For more information please refer to: Emmer et al., Eukaryotic Cell 2011



L. infantum


  • Promastigote and amastigote life stages (Brotherton et al.)
    L. infantum (MHOM/MA/67/ITMAP-263) promastigotes and amastigotes were purified and whole cell lysates were fractionated by free-flow electrophoresis. Fractions from FFE were pooled and analyzed by 1DE- or 2DE- LC-MS/MS.
    For more information please refer to: Brotherton et al., Journal Proteome Research 2010

  • Metacyclogenesis (Ouellette, et al. unpublished)
    Evidence of protein expression in L. infantum proteins in the metacyclic stage. Parasites were analyzed on 2D gel, followed by pre-fractionation by free-flow electrophoresis and Mass Spec analysis by Marc Ouellette's group at the Centre de Recherche en Infectiologie de l'Universite Laval, Quebec, Canada.


L. donovani


  • Posttranslationally modified proteins from promastigote, amastigote, and differentiating promastigotes (Rosenzweig et al.)
    Axenic promastigotes, differentiating promastigotes in axenic culture, and amastigotes were isolated from L. donovani 1SR strain. Proteins precipitated from whole cell lysates of each life stage were labeled with iTRAQ reagent and analyzed by two dimensional LC-MS/MS. All identifications of each modified peptide were grouped according to modification type.
    For more information please refer to: Rosenzweig et al., Proteomics 2008

  • Exosome proteome (Silverman et al.)
    Exosomes purified from L. donovani Sudan S2 promastigotes were solubilized in trypsin digestion buffer. Tryptic peptides were analyzed by LC-MS/MS and mass spec data was searched against the L. major protein database.
    For more information please refer to: Silverman et al., Journal Cell Science 2010


L. braziliensis


  • Promastigote secretome (Cuervo et al.)
    Secreted proteins, precipitated from media after incubating with L. braziliensis IOC-L 2463 promastigotes, were resuspended and analyzed by 2DE, LC-MS/MS. Peptide discovery was performed against NCBI nonredundant database (V 050623).
    For more information please refer to: Cuervo et al., Journal Proteomics 2009


L. mexicana


  • Amastigote secretome (Paape et al.)
    The secreted protein fraction of amastigotes (L. mexicana mexicana MNYC/BZ/62/M379) were purified from infected host cells by FACS sorting and low speed centrifugation and analyzed by LC-MS/MS.
    For more information please refer to: Paape et al., Molecular Biochemical Parasitology 2010

Find genes that have evidence for protein expression

  • T. vaginalis subcellular fraction
    The secreted protein fraction of amastigotes (L. mexicana mexicana MNYC/BZ/62/M379) were purified from infected host cells by FACS sorting and low speed centrifugation and analyzed by LC-MS/MS.
    Data provided by the Patricia Johnson laboratory.

Find genes that have evidence for protein expression. Please refer to the original papers for more information on the experiments and experimental conditions.
For details on Data Sources and Methods please access specific component sites information.

The search uses WU BLAST.

question.name: GenesByMotifSearch
question.summary: Find genes whose protein product contains a motif pattern that you specify, e.g.: two cysteines followed by one or more hydrophobic amino acids, followed by arginine, then lysine.
question.description:
Find genes whose protein product contains a motif pattern that you specify., e.g. "CC6+RK", which means "two cysteines followed by one or more hydrophobic amino acids, followed by arginine, then lysine". The pattern need not be well conserved. If you can describe it in words, you can probably use this tool to create an "expression" that can search other proteins for similar patterns.

Another example is the pattern of the Pexel motif, which can be represented as "R.L.[EQD]", meaning "an arginine, then any amino acid, then a leucine, then any amino acid, then either an aspartic acid, a glutamic acid, or a glutamine".

Specify the pattern with a (Perl style) "regular expression". (Regular expressions are more powerful than PROSITE patterns.) For a description of how to create regular expressions, please see the Regular Expression Tutorial.

The following codes can be used to represent classes of amino acids.
AA property Amino acids Code
Acidic DE 0
Alcohol ST 1

question.name: GenesByInterproDomain
question.summary: Find genes containing a specified protein domain from the InterPro database.
question.description:
Find genes whose predicted protein contains a domain from the InterPro set of domain databases. The domain matches are identified by the InterProScan program. To learn more about InterPro see the InterPro tutorial.

First choose a member database.

Then begin typing the domain name, or part of it (accession or description). You will be prompted with all possible domains that match what you have typed in the genomes within this database.

question.name: GenesByGoTerm
question.summary: Find genes by Gene Ontology (GO) term for molecular function, biological process or subcellular localization.
question.description:
Find genes by Gene Ontology (GO) term for molecular function, biological process or subcellular localization. The search finds genes with the GO term you specify and genes with terms that are specializations of your term (is-a). You may use '*' as a wild card character. For a list of GO terms, try the AmiGO browser. For GO IDs, include the GO prefix as in "GO:0003824".

GO term annotation was provided by the sequencing and annotation centers, and was inferred from similarity to protein domains from the InterPro databases.

question.name: GenesByOrthologPattern
question.summary: Find genes that have a specified orthology-based phylogenetic profile.
question.description:
Find genes that have a specified orthology-based phylogenetic profile. The phylogenetic profile of a gene is a series of "present" or "absent" calls, reflecting the presence or absence of a putative ortholog in all genomes used.

An OrthoMCL analysis of the proteins of select species which are each placed in an ortholog group. From your favorite gene's perspective, the other species that are included in that gene's ortholog group can be thought of as a phylogenetic profile.

Use this search to define a pattern across those ortholog groups, and find genes that match that pattern. The pattern is a specification, for each species, of "include", "exclude", or "no constraints." Click on the radio button next to a species to toggle through the three states. (A means "include", an means "exclude" and means "no constraints".)

For example, to find genes that are present in Apicomplexa but not in humans, click on Apicomplexa until you see a and click on Homo sapiens until you see an .

question.name: GenesByPhylogeneticTree
question.summary: Find G. lamblia genes that have computed phylogenetic trees available.
question.description: Find G. lamblia Assemblage A isolate WB genes that have computed phylogenetic trees available. A list of genes is returned that all have a link to a phylogenetic tree on the gene record page.

question.name: GeneBySingleLocusTag
question.summary: Find a gene by its ID.
question.description: Find a gene by its ID. The search is case insensitive. Asterisks can be used as wild cards (e.g. ' PF11_* '). Genes whose IDs have changed can be found by either old or new ID. GI numbers (e.g. 23508535), Entrez Protein Locus IDs (e.g. NP_701204.1), PDB IDs (e.g. 1HN6), or GenBank IDs (e.g. AAB36701.1) can also be used.

GI numbers (e.g. 23508535), Entrez Protein Locus IDs (e.g. NP_701204.1), PDB IDs (e.g. 1HN6), or GenBank IDs (e.g. AAB36701.1) can also be used.

question.name: GeneByLocusTag
question.summary: Find a gene by its ID.
question.description: Find genes by a list of IDs. Either enter the ID list manually, or upload a plain text file that contains the list. IDs can be delimited by a comma, a semi colon, or any white spaces. For example, a list can be in the following form: "NCU06658, NCU06659, Ndisc8579_106685". The ids you provide cannot have wild cards for this search. If you want search genes with wild cards, you can use the "Gene Id" quick search at the top of the page.

Find genes by a list of IDs. Either enter the ID list manually, or upload a plain text file that contains the list. IDs can be delimited by a comma, a semi colon, or any white spaces. For example, a list can be in the following form: %%defaultGeneList%%. The ids you provide cannot have wild cards for this search. If you want search genes with wild cards, you can use the "Gene Id" quick search at the top of the page.
Note: when searching for multiple IDs it is possible that not all will be found in the database. This may be due to changes in the annotation or unavailability of ID mapping. At present we do not have a mechanism to inform you which IDs from your input did not match anything in the database.

question.name: GeneByLocusTag
question.summary: Find a gene by its ID.
question.description: Find genes by a list of IDs. Either enter the ID list manually, or upload a plain text file that contains the list. IDs can be delimited by a comma, a semi colon, or any white spaces. Also, the list may contain gene IDs from any of the EuPathDB organisms. For example, a list can be in the following form: "PF11_0344, cgd7_230, TGME49_039250, TVAG_386090, GL50803_5213". The ids you provide cannot have wild cards for this search. If you want search genes with wild cards, you can use the "Gene Id" quick search at the top of the page.

question.name: GenesByTextSearch
question.summary: Find genes with a text search against their product name, notes, GO, EC, Domains, NRDB, or metabolic pathways.
question.description:
Find genes by searching text annotations. The search compares your term against the text in the fields you specify, returning genes that have a match. Remember to select your species/organism of interest (more than one species may be selected).

Hints: The search is similar to Google -- if you enter multiple words, genes that match more of those words will have a better score than those that match fewer of the words. If the words are found close together, that also improves the score. Higher scores appear at the top of your result list. Use quotation marks to find exact phrase matches: for example to find the exact phrase ABC transporter, type "ABC transporter" in the search window. You may use an asterisks '*' as a wild card character: for example to find all compound words that start with phospho (ie. phosphodiesterase), type phospho* in the search window.

Note about non-relevant results: Depending on how you configure it, this text search may return "non-relevant" genes (false positives). The search mechanically matches the term you supply against the fields described in the Fields parameter. The presence of your term in that field does not necessarily mean that the term actually describes the gene. The term may be mentioned in that field for less relevant reasons. To work around this, please choose the Fields you want to search carefully, and then, before drawing any conclusions, review the reference to your term in all matched fields in the gene page to confirm the meaning of its mention. The "Gene product" field is the most stringent and is unlikely to return false positives.

question.description: Find all genes from one or more species/organism.

question.name: GenesByBindingSiteFeature
question.summary: Find Genes which have a specified transcription factor binding site upstream or dowstream.
question.description:
Plasmodium falciparum transcription-factor binding sites - Manuel Llinas

The DNA sequence motifs bound by each ApiAP2 transcription factor were derived from protein binding microarray data using P. falciparum AP2 domains. Protein binding microarrays are non-organism specific and contain matches to all contiguous 10-mers at least once and non-palindromic 8-mers up to 32 times. The DNA motifs were determined using purified recombinant AP2 domains and the resulting position weight matrix for each AP2 domain was used to search upstream regions for significant matches. The AP2 domain that binds to each motif is indicated at the end of the gene ID. Binding sites are based on sequence matches only and have not been verified in vivo.
For further information, contact Manuel Llinas: manuel@princeton.edu

References:

Identification and genome-wide mapping of DNA binding specificities for the ApiAP2 family of regulators from the malaria parasite.Manuscript submitted. 2010 Campbell et al

Compact, universal DNA microarrays to comprehensively determine transcription-factor binding site specificities

The AP2 motifs were mapped to the genome using the algorithm described in the following paper: Identification of transcription factor binding sites in the human genome sequence
The P value is the probability that the binding site with that score would match at that position given the input DNA (intergenic and telomeric regions). For example, a P value of 1X10-4 means that you would find a good match every 10,000 base pairs on average on that strand.

columnAttribute.name: tfbs_count
columnAttribute.help: Number of binding sites in the selected upstream region of this gene

columnAttribute.name: tfbs_distance
columnAttribute.help: Number of base pairs from the transcript start of this gene

question.name: GenesByChIPchipToxo
question.summary: Find genes with evidence for expression based on ChIP-chip peaks
question.description:
Find all T. gondii genes with evidence for expression based on ChIP-chip peaks.

1Mathieu Gissot, J. Eduardo Fajardo, Louis M. Weiss, Andras Fiser, Kami Kim (Albert Einstein College of Medicine, unpublished)
Two different antibodies were used identifying different chromatin marks which indicate active transcription. Coincident Histone 3 Lysine 4 trimethylation (H3K4me3) and Histone 3 Lysine 9 acetylation (H3K9ac) peaks are highly correlated with active promoters, with H3K4me3 marks oriented closer to the 5' end of the gene. This search allows you to identify genes where the 5' end is within a selected distance (maximum of 3000 bp) from the center of a ChIP-chip peak. A 770,000 Nimblegen oligonucleotide array was custom designed based upon the Release 4 ME49 genomic sequence (63 Mb) with an average oligonucleotide length of 50 bp (isothermal hybridization design) and spacing of approximately 80 bp. Tachyzoites of CTG (Type III), PLK (ME49 clone, Type II) and RH (Type I) strains were harvested 36 hours after inoculation of human foreskin fibroblasts and chromatin immunoprecipitation hybridization (ChIP-chip) performed as described in Gissot et al PLoS Pathogens 2007.

2Bougdour, Maubon, Baldacci, Ortet, Bastien, Bouillon, Barale, Pelloux, Menard, Hakimi (Drug-inhibition of HDAC3 and epigenetic control of differentiation in Apicomplexa parasites J. Exp. Med. 2009
Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and microarray hybridization (Nimblegen arrays), we analyzed the patterns of DNA-bound Histone H4(K5-K8-K12-K16) acetylation after 4 hours treatment of RH strain with DMSO (control) or 40 nM of FR235222 (named previously drug A) which is a Toxoplasma-specific HDAC inhibitor. ChIP-on-chip isolated DNA samples (input and immunopurified DNA) were arrayed on custom synthetic oligo arrays (387,000 features per array, 46-50-mer oligos, 2 arrays for the whole genome; Nimblegen)

3Data provided by Dr. Mohamed-Ali Hakimi (unpublished).

question.name: GenesByChIPchipPlasmo
question.summary: Find genes with evidence for expression based on ChIP-chip peaks
question.description:
Find all P. falciparum genes with evidence for expression based on ChIP-chip peaks.



1Chromatin Immunoprecipitation data from Artur Scherf lab
Chromatin immunoprecipitation to identify histone modifications (H3K9me3, H3K9Ac, H3K4me3, H4K20me3) in Plasmodium falciparum wild type and Sir2 knock-outs. Contact Artur Scherf, artur.scherf@pasteur.fr, Unit de Biologie des Interactions Hote-Parasite.i.

2Chromatin Immunoprecipitation data from Till Voss lab
Genome-wide association of Pf Heterochromatin protein 1 (Hp-1) with virulence gene clusters. We identified 425 PfHP1-bound genes by ChIP-on-CHIP - almost all of which code for expor ted (predicted) virulence genes including all var genes, rifs, stevor, pfmc-2tm and others. Contact Till Voss, till.voss@unibas.ch, for further information

question.description:
Find Plasmodium falciparum, Giardia Assemblage A isolate WB and Toxoplasma gondii genes with evidence of expression based on SAGE tag experiments. Set the 5' and 3' distance to greater than 0 to include tags in the UTRs (or beyond). The result includes a column showing the summed frequency of all tags thus associated with a gene.

This search sums the counts of SAGE tags falling within/near a gene. See the related SAGE Tags by Expression Level search to find counts for a specific SAGE tag and also for interrogating SAGE tags which don't align to predicted genes.


The data available for Toxoplasma gondii is from a study conducted by Radke et. al. where SAGE tag libraries were generated from T. gondii parasites at specific stages of development. The data available through ToxoDB includes 3' (3p) SAGE tag libraries only. Abbreviations are as follows:
sp   = Oocyst population that contains sporozoites (VEG strain).
d4   = Day 4 parasites (post-inoculation of human foreskin fibroblast cells (HFFs)).
d6   = Day 6 parasites (post-inoculation of HFFs) -- rapidly growing in the second host cell.
d7   = Day 7 parasites (post-inoculation of HFFs) -- parasites undergo a growth shift at this point.
d15 = Day 15 parasites (post-inoculation of HFFs) -- The parasites are slow growing and include a mixture of tachyzoites and bradyzoites.
ph   = VEG parasites that were alkaline-differentiated into bradyzoites for 72 hours.
rh    = TypeI-RH.
b7   = TypeII-ME49B7.
msj = TypeIII-VEGmsj.

question.name: GenesByESTOverlap
question.summary: Find genes with evidence of expression based on expressed sequence tags (ESTs)
question.description: Find genes with evidence of expression based on expressed sequence tags (ESTs). NOTE: you can visualize the EST alignments by clicking on the "View this sequence in the genome browser" link and turning on the EST Alignments track.

Find genes with evidence of expression based on expressed sequence tags (ESTs). For example: What P. falciparum genes overlap with aligned ESTs from the 3D7 gametocyte library? NOTE: you can visualize the EST alignments by clicking on the "View this sequence in the genome browser" link and turning on the EST Alignments track.

Find genes with evidence of expression based on expressed sequence tags (ESTs). Select an organism (more than one may be selected) then choose an organism-specific EST library (more than one EST library may be selected). To select more than one EST library press the shift or the ctrl/command keys while selecting items from the EST library list (The shift key allows selection of a subset of sequential libraries, while the ctrl (PCs)/command (MACs) key allows the selection of non-sequential items).
Advanced parameters can be modified for a more specific search (please go to the corresponding help sections for more information).
NOTE: you can visualize the EST alignments by clicking on the "View this sequence in the genome browser" link and turning on the EST Alignments track.

Find genes with evidence of expression based on expressed sequence tags (ESTs). For example: What P. falciparum genes overlap with aligned ESTs from the 3D7 gametocyte library?

EST overlap with an annotated gene is a useful way to verify gene predictions but the absence of overlapping ESTs does not mean that a gene is not expressed. Showing the advanced parameters allows you to specify more or less stringent alignment and overlap parameters.

Find C. muris and C. parvum genes having overlap with an Expressed sequence tag (EST).

EST overlap with an annotated gene is a useful way to verify gene predictions. Ideally we would have EST sequences for each gene prediction, but this is not the case in Cryptosporidium . Useful lengths of sequence overlap between an EST sequence and a predicted gene sequence are usually 50nt or greater. C. muris and C. parvum ESTs were clustered against their respective genomes. The cluster consensus sequences are available via the graphical genome browser on the gene record pages. Genes from the MRC-LMB sequencing of chromosome 6 are not included at this time.

question.name: GiardiaGenesByDifferentialExpression
question.displayName: G.l. Stress Response in Trophozoites (direct comparison)
question.summary: Find genes by differential expression analysis
question.description:
Find genes whose expression was found to be up-regulated or down-regulated in Giardia lamblia Trophozoites after stress induction by PaGE differential expression analysis.


1Giardia lamblia strain WBC6 (ATCC catalog No. 50803) trophozoites were grown in 11 ml TYI-S-33 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and bovine bile.Parasites were grown to confluency at 37 degrees C, and medium was replaced prior to stress induction. Redox stress was induced by addition of Dithiothreitol (DTT, Fluka 43817) for 30 minutes to final concentrations of 7.1 mM, 14.2 mM or 21.3 mM. In the control cultures an equivalent amount of water was used. Temperature stress (40 degrees C) was induced by incubating parasites for 30 minutes at 40 degrees C (control 37 degrees C).


2Giardia lamblia strain WBC6 (ATCC catalog No. 50803) trophozoites were grown in 11 ml TYI-S-33 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and bovine bile. Parasites were grown to confluency at 37 degrees C, and medium was replaced prior to stress induction. Redox stress was induced by addition of Dithiothreitol (DTT, Fluka 43817) to a final concentration of 14.2 mM for 30 minutes, 1 or 2 hours. In the control culture an equivalent amount of water was used.


Data provided by the Hehl lab (C. Spycher, L. Morf) and the Functional Genomics Center Zurich ( H. Rehrauer, C. Aquino Fournier, J. Sobek).

question.name: GiardiaGenesByDifferentialExpressionTwo
question.summary: Find genes by differential expression analysis
question.description:
Find genes whose expression was found to be up-regulated or down-regulated in Giardia lamblia Trophozoites after encystation by PaGE differential expression analysis.

Two protocols were used to encyst parasites in vitro: the standard 2-step, and a lipid (cholesterol) starvation protocol. Encystation-specific changes of gene expression were analyzed at 45 minutes, 3 and 7 hours post induction.

Morf L, Spycher C, Rehrauer H, Fournier CA, Morrison HG, Hehl AB. The transcriptional response to encystation stimuli in Giardia lamblia is restricted to a small set of genes.

question.description:
Find genes that are differentially expressed based on growth conditions. Select a comparison and reference growth conditions, your desired fold induction and the direction of regulation.
Interaction experiments were performed between G. intestinalis GL50803 and 21-day differentiated Caco-2 cells. Trophozoites were separated and collected from the interaction cultures at 1.5 h, 6 h and 18 h time points. In addition, trophozoites of the same time points were harvested from standard TYI-S-33 cultures and from cultures in only interaction medium (DMEM). Microarrays of all samples and time points were performed with a common reference, a pool of trophozoites from the 0 hr time point of three replicate experiments. At least two 2-channel arrays were performed for each time point.

question.name: GenesByTimeSeriesFoldChangeBradyRoos
question.summary: Identify genes induced under bradyzoite conditions (alkaline media, nitroprusside, or CO2-depletion) in Pru or RH strains. (Roos).
question.description:
The goal of this experiment was to observe early transcriptional changes in T. gondii during tachyzoite-to-bradyzoite differentiation. In order to differentiate treatment- specific effects from bradyzoite-specific events, multiple induction conditions and strains were analyzed. Results from this analysis demonstrate a core set of early transcriptional events characterizing bradyzoite induction.

Human foreskin fibroblast (HFF) cells grown in D10 media within T25 flasks were inoculated with roughly 10,000 T. gondii parasites for each experiment. Two strains of T. gondii parasites were used in this analysis: type II Prugniaud lacking HXGPRT, and type I RH lacking HXGPRT and UPRT. A total of three experimental conditions were used to promote in vitro bradyzoite differentiation: Alkaline conditions (D10 media adjusted to pH 8.2), CO2 starvation (MEM with 10% FBS, 25mM HEPES, pH 7.2 grown without CO2), and sodium nitroprusside (SNP) exposure (D10 with 100uM SNP). All conditions were applied 6hr post-inoculation and each media was exchanged every twelve hours post-inoculation.

question.description:
The goal of this experiment was to observe substantial transcriptional changes in T. gondii during tachyzoite-to-bradyzoite differentiation. Analysis of the two studied strains suggests that transcriptional changes associated with bradyzoite differentiation occur early after induction (within hours).

Human foreskin fibroblast (HFF) cells grown in D10 media within T25 flasks were inoculated with roughly 10,000 T. gondii parasites for each experiment. Two strains of T. gondii parasites were used in this analysis: type II Prugniaud lacking HXGPRT, and type III VEG. CO2 starvation (MEM with 10% FBS, 25mM HEPES, pH 7.2 grown without CO2) was used to induce in vitro bradyzoite differentiation.

question.name: GenesByTimeSeriesFoldChangeBradyBoothroyd
question.summary: Identify genes induced under bradyzoite conditions (alkaline media) in Pru strain. (Boothroyd).
question.description: T. gondii Type II Prugniaud parasites lacking HXGPRT were inoculated at and MOI of 2 and differentiated in RPMI 1640 lacking sodium bicarbonate, low FCS, and high pH (8.1). RNA was collected from either tachyzoite (2 days post inoculation before monolayer lysis) or bradyzoite cultures (2-days, 3-days and 4-days of induction). The cultures were syringe lysed at the respective time points with a 27 gauge needle. One spin was performed at 500g for 1.5 minutes to pellet intact cells and large debris but not parasites. The sup was taken and then spun at 1500g for 7 minutes to collect parasites. Spins were done at 0 degrees C. The RNA was collected by Trizol extraction and stored in water. Arrays were performed with 5ug of total RNA (where at least >50% of the RNA was Toxoplasma based on comparative quantification of Toxo versus human large ribosomal RNA by gel electrophoresis) using the standard Affymetrix protocol for single amplification cRNA preparation.

question.name: GenesByExpressionPercentileBoothroyd
question.summary: Find T. gondii genes that show expression percentile differences along the oocyst, tachyzoite, and bradyzoite development in the type II strain M4.
question.description:
Find genes based on your specified expression percentile and life cycle stage. Transcriptome analysis of oocyst,tachyzoite and bradyzoite development in the type II strain M4.

There were three primary objectives to the overall experiment.

     I. Describe the transcriptome of the oocyst through its development beginning with the freshly excreted, unsporulated oocyst at "Day 0" to a fully sporulated and mature oocyst at "Day 10" and including a mid-sporulation time-point at "Day 4".
     II. Compare the transcriptomes of in vitro (4 and 8 days post infection (dpi)) vs. in vivo (21 dpi) derived bradyzoites.
     III. Compare expression data from three life stages (oocyst, bradyzoite and tachyzoite) from the same parasite isolate, M4. This isolate has been characterized as a Type II strain.

The RNA was derived from parasites donated by the Moredun Research Institute, Edinburgh, Scotland, UK and belong to the same original isolate (T. gondii M4: J. Gutierrez et al. Veterinary Parasitology 172 (2010) 8-15.)

More specifically, RNA samples were obtained from:

     1. Oocysts harvested from kitten feces and purified for RNA extraction at Day 0, (not sporulated), Day 4 post-induction of sporulation (mid-sporulation) and Day 10 post-induction of sporulation. Oocysts were collected and combined from two kittens that were infected with the same starting material (mouse brains containing bradyzoite cysts). Duplicate samples were obtained from feces collected and purified on separate days.
     2. Bradyzoite cysts harvested from the brains of mice that were infected with oocysts (obtained from the oocysts harvested from kittens as described for the oocyst RNA). Mice were treated with 0.44 μg/ml sulfadiazine in their water days 11-21 pi to enable a chronic infection state. Mice were sacrificed on day 21 for cyst purification.
     3. In vitro 4 and 8 dpi bradyzoite and 2 dpi tachyzoite samples are from separately infected cultures of human foreskin fibroblasts (HFF) (replicate flasks for each condition and time-point were infected on the same day). Samples were harvested independently and kept separate for all the subsequent processing and labeling steps. Bradyzoite differentiation was induced by growth under low serum (1%) high pH (8.0) conditions without supplemented CO2 as described (Fux, B. et. al. Infect Immun 75:2580-90, 2007).

Authors: Heather Fritz*, Kerry R. Buchholz*, Patricia Conrad, and John C. Boothroyd. (* these authors contributed equally.)

question.name: GenesByExpressionPercentileSullivan
question.displayName: T.g. GCN5-A Alkaline Stress Response v. Wild Type (percentile)
question.summary: Find T. gondii genes that show expression percentile differences in TgGCN5-A null mutant compared to wildtype when stressed by alkaline culture conditions.
question.description:
Differential expression of TgGCN5-A null mutant under Alkaline growth conditions compared to wild type.

Disruption of the gene encoding for TgGCN5-A in type I RH strain did not produce a severe phenotype under normal culture conditions, but here we show that the TgGCN5-A null mutant is deficient in responding to alkaline pH, a common stress used to induce bradyzoite differentiation in vitro. We performed a genome- wide analysis of the Toxoplasma transcriptional response to alkaline pH stress, finding that parasites deleted for TgGCN5-A fail to up-regulate 74% of the stress response genes that are induced 2-fold or more in wild-type. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation, we verify an enrichment of TgGCN5-A at the upstream regions of genes activated by alkaline pH exposure. The TgGCN5-A knockout is also incapable of up-regulating key marker genes expressed during development of the latent cyst form, and is impaired in its ability to recover from alkaline stress. Complementation of the TgGCN5-A knockout restores the expression of these stress-induced genes and reverses the stress recovery defect.

Authors: Arunasalam Naguleswaran, Eliana V. Elias, Jeanette McClintick, Howard J. Edenberg, William J. Sullivan Jr

question.name: GenesByExpressionPercentileCarruthers
question.summary: Find T. gondii genes that show expression differences in an intracellular vs. extracellular enviroment.
question.description:
Here we show that host cell transmission of the obligate intracellular parasite Toxoplasma gondii is closely tied to specific cell cycle distributions, with egress and reinvasion occurring most proficiently by parasites in the G1 phase. We also reveal that Toxoplasma undergoes marked changes in mRNA expression when transitioning from the extracellular environment to its intracellular niche. These mRNA level changes reflect a modal switch from expression of proteins involved in invasion, motility and signal transduction in extracellular parasites to expression of metabolic and DNA replication proteins in intracellular parasites.

Three sample types were harvested: extracellular, intracellular 0hr, intracellular 2hr. 2 replicates each. Expression for >80% of the regulated genes exhibits a steady downregulation during invasion.

Authors: Rajshekhar Y. Gaji, Michael S. Behnke, Margaret M. Lehmann, Michael W. White, Vern B. Carruthers

question.name: GenesByExpressionPercentileMatrajt
question.summary: Find genes that are differentially expressed in different pathogensis stages of T. gondii by expression percentiles.
question.description:
Toxoplasma gondii pathogenesis includes the invasion of host cells by extracellular parasites, replication of intracellular tachyzoites, and differentiation to a latent bradyzoite stage. We present the analysis of seven novel T. gondii insertional mutants that do not undergo normal differentiation to bradyzoites. Microarray quantification of the variation in genome-wide RNA levels for each parasite line and times after induction allowed us to describe states in the normal differentiation process, to analyze mutant lines in the context of these states, and to identify genes that may have roles in initiating the transition from tachyzoite to bradyzoite. Gene expression patterns in wild-type parasites undergoing differentiation suggest a novel extracellular state within the tachyzoite stage. All mutant lines exhibit aberrant regulation of bradyzoite gene expression and notably some of the mutant lines appear to exhibit high proportions of the intracellular tachyzoite state regardless of whether they are intracellular or extracellular. In addition to the genes identified by the insertional mutagenesis screen, mixture model analysis allowed us to identify a small number of genes, in mutants, for which expression patterns could not be accounted for using the three parasite states--genes that may play a mechanistic role in switching from the tachyzoite to bradyzoite stage.

Authors: Lescault PJ, Thompson AB, Patil V, Lirussi D, Burton A, Margarit J, Bond J, Matrajt M.

question.summary: Find interacting partners of a specific gene as determined by yeast two-hybrid experiments.
question.description:
Find interacting partners of a specific gene as determined by yeast two-hybrid experiments. This data is available for P. falciparum only.

'Number of searches that found this interaction' or Times reproduced refers to the number of independent yeast two-hybrid screens in which a given interaction was found. Interactions found in two or more yeast two-hybrid screens were independently reproduced, and are thus more likely to be true yeast two-hybrid positives.

'Number of times this interaction was found' or Times observed refers to the total number of times a given interaction was identified in all yeast two-hybrid screens. An interaction can be identified multiple times in the same screen for several reasons: (1) The original yeast cell containing the pair of interacting proteins divided before being plated on selective media; (2) The same prey plasmid was present in the library multiple times and thus gave rise to multiple positive colonies; or (3) The prey gene was present in the library as multiple independent, overlapping fragments, all of which interact with a given bait. Only (3) provides independent confirmation of a putative interaction.

Protein interactions were experimentally determined using the yeast two-hybrid system as described in LaCount DJ, Vignali M, Chettier R, Phansalkar A, Bell R, Hesselberth JR, Schoenfeld LW, Ota I, Sahasrabudhe S, Kurschner C, Fields S, Hughes RE. A protein interaction network of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum. Nature. 2005 438:103-7.

Find interacting partners of a specific gene as determined by yeast two-hybrid experiments. This data is available for S. cerevisiae only.

'Number of searches that found this interaction' or Times reproduced refers to the number of independent yeast two-hybrid screens in which a given interaction was found. Interactions found in two or more yeast two-hybrid screens were independently reproduced, and are thus more likely to be true positives.

'Number of times this interaction was found' or Times observed refers to the total number of times a given interaction was identified in all yeast two-hybrid screens. An interaction can be identified multiple times in the same screen for several reasons: (1) The original yeast cell containing the pair of interacting proteins divided before being plated on selective media; (2) The same prey plasmid was present in the library multiple times and thus gave rise to multiple positive colonies; or (3) The prey\ gene was present in the library as multiple independent, overlapping fragments, all of which interact with a given bait. Only (3) provides independent confirmation of a putative interaction.

question.name: GenesByFunctionalInteraction
question.summary: Find genes of P. falciparum (strain HB3) identified by the plasmoMAP project to have a functional interaction with the given gene.
question.description:
Find Plasmodium falciparum genes identified by the plasmoMAP project to have a functional interaction with the given gene.

Input a gene ID and a minimum interaction likelihood score. Scores range from 2 to 9435, and increasing scores indicate higher confidence. Generally, a likelihood score of 10 or more indicates a high-confidence interaction.

There are 388,969 total predicted protein pairs in the result set, with likelihood scores ranging from 2 to 9435. Below a score of 2, the number of false positives exceed the number of true positives. Most protein-protein interaction pairs (~79%) have a likelihood score of below 10, while about 20% of the pairs have a likelihood score between 10 and 9435 (only 251 pairs, or about 0.06% of the total, have a likelihood score above 100).

Empirical observations of the results show that while many pairs with very low likelihood scores (say between 2-4) are biologically valid, the predicted interactions are likely to be highly accurate as the scores approach a value of 10. In the published manuscript, a score of 14 was used to isolate a high-confidence subset of interactions, where the number of true positives was about 10 times greater than the number of false positives.

question.name: GenesByDifferentialMeanExpression
question.summary: Find genes by differential expression (fold-change) in Sir2 and invasion pathway KO studies
question.description:
Find genes based on fold-change differences in expression by comparing assays of P. falciparum RNA when the Sir2 histone deacetylase gene is knocked out, when an erythrocyte binding protein (EBA-175, EBA-140, or pfRh2b) is knocked out, or in their associated controls. Please be aware that these are individual comparisons and not subjected to any statistical analysis.

The data is from a total of 17 microarray experiments performed using an Affymetrix short oligonucleotide platform. This platform contains oligos (25-mers) derived from the predicted coding regions of the entire P. falciparum genome. The Sir2 Knock out (KO) experiments were designed to look at var gene silencing by Sir2 (PF13_0152). The EBA-175 (MAL7P1.176), EBA-140 (MAL13P1.60), and pfRh2b (MAL13P1.176) KOs were performed to study sialic acid-dependent versus sialic acid-independent invasion pathways. W2mef/C4/Nm is a sialic acid-independent clone. The D10 strain naturally is missing the pfRh2b and EBA-140 genes.

Expression values for each probe set were obtained by the gcRMA algorithm. Queries can be performed to retrieve genes with a fold change of expression values greater or equal to the value entered between the reference (denominator) and comparison (numerator) studies chosen.

question.name: GenesByRNASeqPfRBCFoldChange
question.displayName: P.f. post infection (RBC) RNA-seq time series (fold change)
question.summary: Find P. falciparum genes that are differentially expressed between different time points post infection. Select your desired fold induction and the direction of regulation.
question.description:
Find P. falciparum genes that are differentially expressed between different time points post infection.

Total RNA was collected from one synchronous 3D7 parasite population at 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35 and 40 hours post-invasion of intraerythrocytic development. mRNAs were enriched using polyA-selection (Oligotex dT, Qiagen), fragmented and converted to double-stranded cDNA. All samples were prepared for Illumina sequencing using a customized bias-free sample preparation protocol (developed at Stunnenberg lab, which prevents sequence bias) and sequenced for 76bp from one side of each fragment on an Illumina GAII machine.



Normalisation methods presume equal transcriptional activity across stages (i.e. normalize to total signal intensity of arrays or to total RNA-seq tag number for sequencing). However, transcriptional activity has been shown to significantly vary, being low after invasion of a red blood cell and reaching the highest level at trophozoite stage (Sims et al. Eukaryotic Cell, 2009). We observed this variation in overall transcriptional activity in the RNA yield from these stages (see Figure above). Therefore, to provide a better approximation of the true transcriptional activity, tag density (per 1000bp) values at each stage should be adjusted by a scaling factor (see table). This scaling factor is derived from total RNA yield divided by the number of nuclei per infected RBC, to yield a value for the total transcriptional activity per parasite nucleus. Setting the "Apply RNA / nuclei number scaling" parameter to yes will query the scaled data.

Bartfai R, Hoeijmakers WAM, Salcedo-Amaya AM, Smits AH, Janssen-Megens E, et al. (2010). H2A.Z Demarcates Intergenic Regions of the Plasmodium falciparum Epigenome That Are Dynamically Marked by H3K9ac & H3K4me3. PLoS Pathog 6(12): e1001223. doi:10.1371/journal.ppat.1001223

question.summary: Find P. falciparum genes that are differentially expressed between different time points post infection. Select your desired fold induction,the direction of regulation and maximum p-value.
question.description:
Find P. falciparum genes that are differentially expressed between different time points post infection using p-values based on Fisher's Exact Test.

Total RNA was collected from one synchronous 3D7 parasite population at 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35 and 40 hours post-invasion of intraerythrocytic development. mRNAs were enriched using polyA-selection (Oligotex dT, Qiagen), fragmented and converted to double-stranded cDNA. All samples were prepared for Illumina sequencing using a customized bias-free sample preparation protocol (developed at Stunnenberg lab, which prevents sequence bias) and sequenced for 76bp from one side of each fragment on an Illumina GAII machine.



Normalisation methods presume equal transcriptional activity across stages (i.e. normalize to total signal intensity of arrays or to total RNA-seq tag number for sequencing). However, transcriptional activity has been shown to significantly vary, being low after invasion of a red blood cell and reaching the highest level at trophozoite stage (Sims et al. Eukaryotic Cell, 2009). We observed this variation in overall transcriptional activity in the RNA yield from these stages (see Figure above). Therefore, to provide a better approximation of the true transcriptional activity, tag density (per 1000bp) values at each stage should be adjusted by a scaling factor (see table). This scaling factor is derived from total RNA yield divided by the number of nuclei per infected RBC, to yield a value for the total transcriptional activity per parasite nucleus. Setting the "Apply RNA / nuclei number scaling" parameter to yes will query the scaled data.

Bártfai R, Hoeijmakers WAM, Salcedo-Amaya AM, Smits AH, Janssen-Megens E, et al. (2010). H2A.Z Demarcates Intergenic Regions of the Plasmodium falciparum Epigenome That Are Dynamically Marked by H3K9ac & H3K4me3. PLoS Pathog 6(12): e1001223. doi:10.1371/journal.ppat.1001223

question.name: GenesByRNASeqPfRBCExprnPercentile
question.displayName: P.f. post infection (RBC) RNA-seq time series (percentile)
question.description:
Find P. falciparum genes based on percentile expression at different time points post infection.



Normalisation methods presume equal transcriptional activity across stages (i.e. normalize to total signal intensity of arrays or to total RNA-seq tag number for sequencing). However, transcriptional activity has been shown to significantly vary, being low after invasion of a red blood cell and reaching the highest level at trophozoite stage (Sims et al. Eukaryotic Cell, 2009). We observed this variation in overall transcriptional activity in the RNA yield from these stages (see Figure above). Therefore, to provide a better approximation of the true transcriptional activity, tag density (per 1000bp) values at each stage should be adjusted by a scaling factor (see table). This scaling factor is derived from total RNA yield divided by the number of nuclei per infected RBC, to yield a value for the total transcriptional activity per parasite nucleus. Note that the current search does not take this into account but may be implemented in a subsequent release.

Total RNA was collected from one synchronous 3D7 parasite population at 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35 and 40 hours post-invasion of intraerythrocytic development. mRNAs were enriched using polyA-selection (Oligotex dT, Qiagen), fragmented and converted to double-stranded cDNA. All samples were prepared for Illumina sequencing using a customized bias-free sample preparation protocol (developed at Stunnenberg lab, which prevents sequence bias) and sequenced for 76bp from one side of each fragment on an Illumina GAII machine.



Bártfai R, Hoeijmakers WAM, Salcedo-Amaya AM, Smits AH, Janssen-Megens E, et al. (2010). H2A.Z Demarcates Intergenic Regions of the Plasmodium falciparum Epigenome That Are Dynamically Marked by H3K9ac & H3K4me3. PLoS Pathog 6(12): e1001223. doi:10.1371/journal.ppat.1001223

question.name: GenesByExpressionPercentileGilchrist
question.displayName: E.histolytica G3 v. HM1:IMSS Transcript Expression (percentile)
question.summary: Find E. histolytica genes that show expression percentile differences in the Ehap-a silenced G3 strain when compared to it's parent, the HM1:IMSS strain.
question.description:
In E. histolytica G3 transfectants, transcriptional silencing of the amoebapore gene (Ehap-a) is accompanied by the down-regulation of two other members of the saposin-like (SAPLIP) gene family (Ehap-b, and EhSaplip1). In the current work, comparison of the G3 transcriptome with that of the parent HM-1:IMSS strain has identified an additional 12 transcripts that were down regulated and 60 which were upregulated at least 7 fold. To investigate this phenomena in more depth, one of the transcripts (TIGR 459.m00030) which was increased >200 fold was further investigated. This E. histolytica specific transcript has the potential to encode a 66 amino acid protein however antibodies raised against a synthetic N-terminal peptide of the 459.m gene did not recognize any such protein in either G3 or HM-1:IMSS amoeba lysates. Treatment of G3 transfectants with the proteasome inhibitor MG-132 to prevent rapid 459.m protein degradation did not result in any detectable 459.m protein. Neither did the transfection of the parent HM-1:IMSS with an expression construct in which the Ehactin gene promoter was used to greatly increase the level of the 459.m transcript. However, transfectants in which the 459.m ORF sequence was placed downstream the GST gene, expressed a fused protein. To determine if the increase in this non-coding mRNA were due to changes in the stability of the 459.m transcript or increased transcription, reporter constructs were generated. The reporter gene was both placed directly 3' of the 459.m gene promoter or fused to the C-terminal sequence of the 459.m ORF. The 459.m promoter, in isolation, was weak and no difference in reporter expression was observed in either G3 or HM-1:IMSS transfectants. The genetic context of the 459.m gene was examined and retroposon elements (EhERE1 and EhSINE) were discovered downstream suggesting the possibility of their involvement in the observed transcription changes.

Authors: Rivka Bracha, Carol A. Gilchrist and David Mirelman

question.name: GenesByExpressionTimingPercentileGilchrist
question.summary: Find E. histolytica genes based on microarray expression percentiles for different strains in specified stage and media.
question.description:
(1) Gene expression in Entamoeba histolytica cysts and trophozoites
RNA was isolated from E. histolytica parasites recently derived from human patients and grown in xenic culture (Robinson's media) for 1-8 weeks. These recently isolated cultures contained a mixture of trophozoites and cysts (as assayed by staining with calcofluor). Two different strains, isolated from different patients, were used. Gene expression in these strains was compared to gene expression in multiple E. histolytica strains (HMI:IMSS, Rahman and 200:NIH) that contained only trophozoites, which had been grown in axenic culture (TYI-S-33) for > 10 years, using a full genome Affymetrix-platform microarray. Multiple lines of evidence suggest that many genes differentially expressed between these two conditions (recent isolates vs. long term lab growth) are developmentally regulated.

All samples were isolated using Trizol and samples other than the cyst containing clinical isolate samples were further purified with the Qiagen RNeasy kit (clinical isolates produced insufficient RNA for cleanup). Samples GSM154008 (HM1replicate 3) and GSM154011 (Rahman replicate 3) were amplified using the SPIA protocol, and hybridized and scanned at VBI. All other samples were processed entirely by Stanford PAN facility. Samples GSM154022, GSM154023, and GSM154024 (the cyst containing clinical samples) were amplified 2 rounds using the standard affy T7 procedure. All others had sufficient RNA and only underwent the standard affy in vitro transcription labeling protocol.
GEO Dataset: Gene expression in Entamoeba histolytica cysts and trophozoites

(2) An Affymetrix platform gene expression array was designed for this analysis that included probe sets for 9435 open reading frames (ORFs) and 9066 5' and 3' flanking regions. Transcripts were detected for > 80% of all ORFs. A total of 523 transcripts (5.2% of all E. histolytica genes) were significantly changed in amoebae isolated from the intestine on Days 1 and 29 after infection: 326 and 109 solely on Days 1 and 29, and 88 on both days. Quantitative real-time reverse transcriptase PCR confirmed these changes in 11/12 genes tested using mRNA isolated from an additional six mice.
GEO Dataset: Impact of intestinal colonization and invasion on the Entamoeba histolytica transcriptome.


For further details, please refer,
Gilchrist CA, Houpt E, Trapaidze N, Fei Z et al. Impact of intestinal colonization and invasion on the Entamoeba histolytica transcriptome.
Mol Biochem Parasitol 2006 Jun;147(2):163-76. PMID: 16569449

Ehrenkaufer GM, Haque R, Hackney JA, Eichinger DJ et al. Identification of developmentally regulated genes in Entamoeba histolytica: insights into mechanisms of stage conversion in a protozoan parasite.
Cell Microbiol 2007 Jun;9(6):1426-44. PMID: 17250591

question.name: GenesByExpressionPercentileBrucei5stg
question.summary: Find T.brucei genes based on your specified expression percentile and lifecycle stage.
question.description:
Find genes based on your specified expression percentile and lifecycle stage.

Whole genome comparison of RNA levels for both protein coding genes and structural RNAs in five different life cycle stages: in vivo slender bloodstream form, in vivo stumpy bloodstream form, cultured bloodstream form, log-phase procyclic culture form and stationary-phase procyclic culture form. RNA from three independent biological replicates from five different life cycle stages were hybridized to Nimblegen arrays (Madison,WI USA) that contained 8 probes per open reading frame and 3 probes per structural RNA spotted three times per array. For this experiment, in the cases where the probe set mapped to near-identical genes, data was assigned to a single representative gene. (see Jensen et al. PMID: 19840382.)

question.name: GenesByExpressionPercentileLinfantum
question.summary: Find L.infantum genes based on your specified expression percentile and time point.
question.description:
Find genes based on your specified expression percentile and time point.


Axenic promastigote-to-amastigote differentiation of Leishmania donovani was induced by inoculating late-log phase promastigotes in medium 199 at pH 5.5 containing 25% fetal bovine serum and incubating them at 37C in 5% CO2 environment. RNA (and protein) was extracted from the cultures at 0 (promastigotes), 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, 10, 15, 24 and 144 (mature amastigotes) hr after exposure to the differentiation signal. cDNA was prepared by reverse transcription using random primers, labeled according to Nimblegen's standard protocol, and hybridized to a Nimblegen array based on the L. infantum v 3.0 sequence, supplemented by L. major sequence for some genes. Each protein-coding gene was represented by eight probes and placed on the microarray chip in triplicate. A total of 16 hybridizations were performed, one for each time-point in two biological replicates of this experiment. The raw data were subjected to quantile normalization across all chips, and a single value for each probe determined using a Tukey Biweight median value of the triplicates on each chip. A single CDS-level value for each chip was similarly determined by a Tukey Biweight median of all probes that map to a given gene. The gene-level signals were then log2-scaled to the corresponding 0 hour (promastigote) signal.


This work was carried out by Tami Lahav, Neta Holland, Hanna Volpin & Dan Zilberstein at the Technion Institute, Israel and Amanda Anderson- Green, Dhileep Sivam and Peter Myler at Seattle Biomedical Research Institute, USA and is described in further detail in Sivam et al. (manuscript in preparation).

question.name: GenesByExprPercentileTbRNADegrd
question.summary: Find T. brucei genes based on your specified expression percentile and sample.
question.description:
Find T. brucei genes based on your specified expression percentile and sample.

In this experiment, the role of major 5'-3' exoribonuclease in transcriptome-wide mRNA degradation was explored, to investigate the balance between mRNA abundance and degradation in the protist T. brucei, which lacks control of RNA polymerase II initiation. It was found that mRNA half-lives varied over about 2 orders of magnitude, with a median half-life of 13 min for total (rRNA-depleted) mRNA. There was a clear correlation between mRNA half-life and mRNA abundance, although not a perfect one. Data for poly(A)+ RNA yielded shorter half-lives than for total RNA, indicating that removal of the poly(A) tail was usually the first step in degradation. Depletion of the major 5'-3' exoribonuclease, XRNA, resulted in marked stabilization of most mRNAs with half-lives under 30 minutes. Thus, on a transcriptome-wide scale, the main pathway of mRNA degradation is deadenylation followed by 5'-3' degradation.
The experimental factors that were varied include, time after transcription inhibition, induction of XRNAi by tetracycline and method of mRNA extraction: ribominus vs. polyA+

To get ribominus mRNA, Ribominus Eukaryotic kit for RNA-seq (Invitrogen, #10837-02 or 10837-08) was used, and to get polyA+ mRNA, Sera-Mag Magnetic Oligo(dT) beads at room temperature for 5 minutes (Illumina sample preparation guide # RS-930-1001) was used. For library construction, mRNA-seq Sample Preparation Kit (Illumina #RS-930-1001) was used.
Illumina Sequencing was performed at the Genecore, EMBL, Heidelberg.

question.name: GenesByExprPercentileTbCellCyc
question.summary: Find T. brucei genes based on your specified expression percentile and sample.
question.description:
Find T. brucei genes based on your specified expression percentile and sample.


In this experiment, analysis of gene expression over the Trypanosoma brucei cell cycle was performed by measuring changes in mRNA abundance on a transcriptome-wide scale. A Double-Cut Elutriation (DCE) procedure was developed to select unperturbed, highly synchronous cell populations from log-phase cultures, and this was compared with synchronization by starvation.

Cell populations were isolated from four time-points post-selection: early (0.5 hours) and late (3 hours) G1 phase, S-phase (5.5 hours), and G2 phase (7.25 hours), each population consisting almost entirely of the desired cell cycle stage. Poly-A+ RNA from these cells was selected and subjected to expression profiling by RNA-seq. Between 13 and 17 million high-quality reads per time-point could be mapped to the T. brucei genome.

for further details, please refer the following manuscript: Stuart K. Archer, Diana Inchaustegui, Rafael Queiroz and Christine Clayton. The Cell Cycle Regulated Transcriptome of Trypanosoma brucei.

question.description:

Expression values at every time point for a gene were normalized to the corresponding expression value of 18s rRNA (see description below for a detailed explanation). Median expression value across the replicates was then computed at each time point for every gene. Expression values for every gene were then standradized to the highest value across time points (with the highest value = 1 and remaining time points scaled proportionally).

For further experiment details please refer the data sources listed below.

question.name: GenesByMicroarrayTimeSeriesSc
question.summary: Identify Saccharomyces cerevisiae genes based on fold change expression difference between a "comparison" time point stage and a reference time point.
question.description:
Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell cycle regulation microarray data.

The following experiments from Spellman et. al. are represented and can be selected from the drop-down menu:

  • Pheromone synchronization time course:  The cell cycle of an asynchronous population of yeast strain DBY8724 was arrested by incubating with alpha-factor for 2 hours (MATa cells arrested in G1).  Time points for microarray analysis were collected for 140 minutes at 7-minute intervals following release from cell cycle arrest.

  • Size-based synchronization time course (elutriation):  Unbudded daughter cells of strain DBY7286 were harvested using an elutriator following sonication (achieves small G1 cells).  Cells were returned to culture and samples for microarray analysis were harvested at 30-minute intervals for 6.5 hours. 

  • Cdc15-based synchronization time course:  The cell cycle of temperature sensitive cdc 15-2 (strain DBY8728) cells was arrested at 37oC for 3.5 hours (cells arrested late in mitosis). Release from cell cycle arrest was achieved by growing cells in permissive temperature (23oC), and cells were harvested at 10-minute intervals for 300 minutes.

  • Transcriptional response to the cyclins Cln3p and Clb2p:  cln3 cell were arrested in late G1 due by temperature-shift inactivating Cdc43p. Clb2 experiment was performed by growing clb2 cells and arresting at M with nocodazole. These RNA were compared to the control wild-type cells arrested at G1 and M using the same approaches. Values represent the relative expression of the mutant to wild-type. cln3-1 is the 40 minute and cln3-2 is the 30 minute experiment. The clb2-1 and clb2-2 represent replicate experiments of the 40-minute time point.

Raw data from this study may be obtained from here.

The following experiment from Cho et. al. is represented and can be selected from the drop-down menu:

  • Cdc28-based synchronization time course:  Cdc 28-13 temperature sensitive cells were arrested late in G1 by incubating at 37oC.  Reinitiation of the cell cycle was achieved by shifting cells to the permissive temperature (25oC).  For microarray analysis cells were collected at 10-minute intervals for 160 minutes.

question.name: GenesByRnaSeqFoldChangeSpomDicer
question.displayName: Spom Dicer Protein Rna Seq (fold change)
question.summary: Identify Schizosaccharomyces pombe genes based on dicer protein analysis
question.description:
Schizosaccharomyces pombe data from Pierre Barraud et al from ETH Zurich on nuclear retention of fission yeast Dicer

Dicer proteins function in RNA interference (RNAi) pathways by generating small RNAs (sRNAs).
The C-terminal domain of S pombe Dicer (Dcr1) structure reveals an unusual double-stranded RNA binding domain (dsRBD) fold embedding a novel zinc-binding motif that is conserved among dicers in yeast and constitutes a novel regulatory module that might represent a potential target for therapeutic intervention with fungal diseases. The RNA-Seq data here is from small RNA libraries from total RNA isolations of wild-type, dcr1Delta, dcr1SHSS, and dcr1Deltaloop2 cells.

PubMed ID: 21847092

T. cruzi lifecycle stages assessed in this study: trypomastigotes, amastigotes, epimastigotes, and metacyclic trypomastigotes.
